original_text: " BLACK FAMILY " The words as big as my granddaughter were painted on our brick wall with black paint . A sense of hopelessness and guilt washed over me . I placed down the bucket as my vision started to become blurry and tainted by tears . I blinked once and they fell and slid down my cheeks . I bit my lower lip in an attempt to stop myself from sobbing . There was no time to cry , there was no point to it . I have to be strong .
text: The word “Black Family” is as big as my granddaughter and is covered with black painted brick walls. A feeling of despair and inwardness was washed away by me. I put down the bucket as my vision began to become blurred and contaminated by tears. I blinked and they fell and slid down my cheek. I bit my lower lip and tried to stop myself from sobing. There is no time to cry, there is no point. I have to be strong.

original_text: King Wenceslas is probably standing on an elevated balcony of his residence when there arose a mild wind , which probably brought with it snowflakes . At a distance he was able to see a man in dire need . A peasant . A farmer or woodcutter , trying to gather some logs to take to his lackluster cottage , with the hope of cooking a meal . The benevolent King is deeply moved by this sight . He inquires of his young servant , and is told the man has come down from near the mountains . Today in a self righteous society , how many would even come out to their balcony , even in fine tropical weather ? How would they respond to the sight of such hopeless despair ?
text: King Wenceslas may have stood on the elevated balcony of his residence, when there was a strong gust of wind that might have brought snowflakes. In the distance, he was able to see a man in desperate need. Farmer. A farmer or wooden carpenter, trying to collect some logs to pick up his boring hut, hoping to cook. The merciful king was deeply moved by this scene. He asked his young servant and was told that the man had come down from the mountains. Today, in a self-righteous society, even in tropical weather, how many people will even walk to their balcony? How will they respond to this desperate despair?

original_text: An American researcher by the name of Rachel Reynolds who wrote about the Nigerian immigrant experience in America for an academic journal was struck by this intriguing dissimilarity in our usage of these expressions . She interviewed Nigerian immigrants in the Chicago area in the course of her research . Even though her interviewees did n't seem content with their material lot in America , they said they were " not surviving " ; that they were just " managing . " She was initially dumb-stricken . When she finally figured out that Nigerians use " managing " to mean " surviving " and " surviving " to mean " managing , " she titled her article : " ' We Are Not Surviving , We Are Managing ' : the Constitution of a Nigerian Diaspora along the Contours of the Global Economy . "
text: A U.S. researcher named Rachel Reynolds, who wrote about the experience of Nigerian immigration in American academic journals, fascinating in our use of these expressions. During the study, she interviewed Nigerian immigrants from the Chicago area. Even though her respondents don’t seem to be content with their material in the United States, they say they “cannot survive.” They are just "managing". She was stupid at first. When she finally discovered that Nigerians used “management” to mean “survival” and “survival” mean “management”, her title was her article: “'We don’t survive, we are managing’: The Constitution of Nigerian diaspora along the outline of the global economy.”

original_text: We 're living in times of absolute insanity , as I 'm pretty sure most people are aware . For a while , waking up every day to check the news seemed to carry with it the same feeling of panic and dread that action heroes probably face when they 're trying to decide whether to cut the blue or green wire on a ticking bomb -- except the bomb 's instructions long ago burned in a fire and imminent catastrophe seems the likeliest outcome . It 's hard to stay that on-edge for that long , though , so it 's natural for people to become inured to this constant chaos , to slump into a malaise of hopelessness and pessimism .
text: We are pretty sure most people know that we live in periods of absolute insanity. There was a time when wake up to check the message every day seemed to carry the same sense of panic and fear, and the action hero might face it when trying to decide whether to cut off blue or green wires on the ticking bomb, except that the bomb's instructions were long ago, burning in a fire and imminent disaster, which seemed to be the most likely result. However, it is difficult to last for so long, so people naturally fall into this constant chaos, into despair and pessimistic discomfort.

original_text: When my dad died unexpectedly in 2014 , he was putting the finishing touches to his forthcoming book , Climate Change and the Health of Nations . The book examines historical records and finds that human health is very sensitive to changes in climate . And drawing on history , he warns that the impacts of climatic change -- such as environmental disaster , increasing temperatures , and food insecurity -- will amplify infectious diseases , under-nutrition , and heat-related deaths , especially among vulnerable populations , such as children and forcibly displaced people .
text: When my father died unexpectedly in 2014, he was making the final touches on his forthcoming book, Climate Change and National Health. The book examines historical records and finds that human health is very sensitive to climate change. He warned that the effects of climate change (such as environmental disasters, temperature increases and food insecurity) will amplify infectious diseases, malnutrition and heat-related deaths, especially among vulnerable groups such as children and those who have been forcibly displaced.

Drifting from a dreamy sung introduction ( " Toe to toe , dancing very close " ) to karaokeish have-a-go rapping , it was the definition of bandwagon-jumping . original_text: Mr. L had been a successful fisherman before the tsunami . With the disaster , he lost his house , livelihood , and personal identity as a productive member of society . Mr. L and his family members had to live in a refugee camp with minimum facilities . A few months after this unbearable catastrophe , Mr. L became depressed . His symptoms included persistent depressed or irritable mood , loss of appetite , sleep disturbance with often early-morning awakening , greatly diminished interest in life activities , fatigue and loss of energy , feelings of worthlessness , feelings of hopelessness , and sometimes thoughts about suicide .
text: Mr. L was a successful fisherman before the tsunami. In the case of this disaster, he lost his house, livelihood and personal identity as a production member of society. Mr. L and his family had to live in a refugee camp with the lowest facilities. A few months after this unbearable disaster, Mr. L became depressed. His symptoms include persistent depression or irritability, loss of appetite, sleep disorders that often wake up in the morning, a significant reduction in interest in life activities, loss of fatigue and energy, feelings of worthlessness, feelings of despair and sometimes thoughts about suicide.

original_text: The nascent Irish community prospered in the booming economy following the Louisiana Purchase in 1803 , as the port of New Orleans grew into the fourth largest port in the world . The Irish 's own magnificent St Patrick 's Church was built in 1833 . By the mid-1850s , the Irish controlled the ocean-to-river vessel transport and were firmly embedded in every line of the city 's business and trade . In fact , New Orleans is home to the first public monument in the United States to honor a woman -- the life-size statue of the great 19th century entrepreneur and philanthropist , Margaret Haughery , an illiterate , widowed immigrant from County Leitrim and life-long resident of the city . The Irish Tiger roared !
text: After Louisiana purchased in 1803, as the port of New Orleans became the fourth largest port in the world, the Irish community flourished in a booming economy. The Irish themselves magnificent St. Patrick's Church was built in 1833. By the mid-1850s, the Irish controlled the transport of the ocean to the river and embedded it firmly in every line of the city's business and trade. In fact, New Orleans is the first public monument in the United States to commemorate a woman - a life-sized statue of the great 19th-century entrepreneur and philanthropist Margaret Haughery, an illiterate widow immigrant of lifelong residents of Letrem County and the city. Irish tiger roars!

People with disabilities may suffer from visual impairment, physical impairment, intellectual impairment, mental disorders, and several other types of chronic diseases.

original_text: There are people in our society who have trouble with walking , moving or talking . Known as disabled to all , they lack the ability to do all kinds of day-to-day activities ; they eventually fail to contribute to the economy and never be part of the independent population of the society . This is what people hold in mind about disabled people . With a view to changing the concept of disability , Physically-challenged Development Foundation ( PDF ) emerged in 2008 as a non-profit organisation yielding the motto : Ability is in our heart . PDF 's objective is to create a better society for the people with disability . In order to achieve this , " PDF Winter Boot Camp 2016 powered by US Embassy Dhaka " took place during 29-30 January , 2016 at Sheikh Hasina Youth Development Institute , Savar , Dhaka .
text: Some people in our society are having trouble walking, moving, or talking. They are called people with disabilities and they lack the ability to engage in various daily activities. They ultimately fail to contribute to the economy and will never be part of the socially independent population. This is what people remember about people with disabilities. To change the concept of disability, the Physical Challenged Development Foundation (PDF) emerged as a nonprofit in 2008, producing the motto: Capability in Our Hearts. The goal of the PDF is to build a better society for people with disabilities. To achieve this goal, the "PDF Winter Training Camp for the U.S. Embassy Dhaka" was held at the Sheikh Hasina Youth Development Institute in Dhakasawa from January 29 to 30, 2016.

'
text: ``I like singing and then calming the audience down, and after it is done, I tell them this: This is a song about love. For me, my music gives me the opportunity to photograph the audience’s faces, make them comfortable and then make them squirm in their seats. You put people in that place. It is your responsibility to be a songwriter when you are on stage. " It was a way of regaining control , of reclaiming identity that you felt was being erased . " Thus , in winter , the women would make varieties of pithes and payesh , many extremely time-consuming , requiring painstaking effort . The fact that her jethima made the labour-intensive khando every winter , till her death when Saha was 14 , reflected that powerful urge to retain a sense of who they were . Similarly , Chaitra Sankranti , an important spring family festival with numerous food rituals marking the end of the Bengali year , continues to be observed . " We make the requisite five bhajas ( fried vegetables ) , two dals , pachan ( a dish using five or seven vegetables ) , payesh and sweets like pata pora ( flat patties of gur-sweetened dough of flour and bananas roasted in banana leaves on the fire ) . "

"It's a way to regain control of the identity you've forgotten." So in winter, women make all kinds of Pithes and Payesh, many very time-consuming and require hard work. Her Jethima did this fact every winter in the labor-intensive khando until she died at the age of 14, reflecting a powerful impulse to maintain a feeling of her identity. Likewise, Chaitra Sankranti is an important spring family festival, with numerous food rituals marking the end of Bangladesh and continuing to be observed. “We made the necessary five Bhajas (fried vegetables), two dals, Pachan (one dish with five or seven vegetables), Payesh and Pata Pora (like Pata Pora) (flat pink flour and flat bread of bananas, bananas bathed in banana leaves on the flames).

original_text: GST preferences ( $17-billion ) As Michael Smart at the University of Toronto estimated , tax preferences under the GST are so large now that the federal GST rate could be cut from 5% to 3% . Even exempting food has a large cost of $3.5-billion . Almost 40% of the tax relief goes to families with more than $100,000 in income -- it would be much more effective and cheaper to boost the refundable GST credit for poor families that really need it . One need not look too far to find other countries have avoided many of these tax preferences , particularly New Zealand , with its low rate and broad base .
text: In the University of Toronto's estimated GST preferences ($17 billion), government tax benefits are so large that federal GST rates can be reduced from 5% to 3%. Even with food exemptions, there is a $3.5 billion fee. Almost 40% of the tax breaks involve families earning more than $100,000 – increasing the refundable GST credit for poor families who really need it will be more efficient and cheaper. One person avoids many of these tax preferences without having to look at other countries, especially New Zealand, which have high rates and broad bases.

original_text: ANNUAL State of Education Report ( ASER ) launched in Islamabad on Wednesday reveals some of the interesting facts and figures . It notes there has been progress in increasing access to education in Pakistan as the number of out-of-school children has dropped from 25 million to 22 million as per government data . However , more remains to be done . Without compromising on access to school , the focus should be on improving the quality . The education budget allocation is now 3.02% of GDP , up from 2.83% last year but is still short of the target . The down side of the situation is that 19% children aged 6-16 still remain out of school . The remaining 81% that are enrolled in the 6-16 age bracket are not learning much either . The seventh ASER survey report also highlighted as per past trends that children enrolled in private schools are performing better compared to those studying in government schools . The number of children out of school should be a cause for concern for the entire nation and especially the Federal and the Provincial governments . It is quite obvious that poverty is the main cause that keeps children away from schools and forces them to do some work to help supplement income of their families . The problem can be addressed to a great extent if number of government schools is increased meaningfully . Government schools charge little or no fee but these are not enough to cater to the needs of growing population . The distance factor and involvement of unbearable travelling expenses also prohibit parents from sending their children to schools . Private schools have mushroomed both in urban and rural areas and they are catering to the need of middle and high income segments of the society but poor families can not afford to get their kids admitted in these schools . Their owners should also realise they have social and national obligations as well and offer some percentage of total admissions to students from poorest of the poor families free of cost . There are also issues of facilities , qualifications of teaching staff and the quality of education being imparted and government should , at least , offer training facilities to all teachers including those employed by private schools .
text: The Annual Education Report (ASER) was launched in Islamabad on Wednesday, revealing some interesting facts and figures. It noted that the number of off-campus children due to government data has dropped from 25 million to 22 million. But there is more work to be done. Without compromising schooling, the focus should be on improving quality. The current education budget allocation is now 3.02% of GDP, up from 2.83% last year, but it still fails to meet its target. The decline in this situation is that 19% of children aged 6-16 still leave school. The remaining 81% also didn’t learn much in the 6-16-year-old age group. The seventh ASER survey also highlighted that children in private schools performed better in the past compared to trends in learning in public schools. The number of children outside the school should attract the attention of the entire country, especially the federal and provincial governments. It is obvious that poverty is the main reason for keeping children away from school and forcing them to do some work to help supplement their family’s income. If the number of public schools increases meaningfully, this problem can be addressed to a large extent. Public schools rarely charge or do not charge fees, but these fees are not enough to meet the needs of population growth. Participation in distance factors and unbearable travel expenses also prohibits parents from sending their children to school. Private schools are excited in urban and rural areas, and they cater to the needs of the mid- and high-income sectors of society, but poor families cannot get their children to be attracted to them. Their owners should also be aware that they also assume social and state obligations and provide a percentage of total enrollment for students from the poorest families for free. There are also issues with facilities, the qualifications of teaching staff and the quality of education provided, and at least the government should provide training facilities for all teachers employed by private schools.

original_text: Founded in 1987 by Dr. Irwin Redlener , singer/ songwriter Paul Simon and program designer Karen Redlener , Children 's Health Fund 's mission is to bring health care directly to homeless and low-income children and their families . Over the past 30 years, CHF has typically provided over 4 million health care encounters in places where doctors and health care providers lack providers.

original_text: If vote-buying is allowed to affect both voter turnout and choice , then political accountability and equality are at risk . original_text: Ishikawa , now 28 , was brought up in Kira , a town of rice paddies and scattered auto-parts factories about an hour from the industrial city of Nagoya , where Toyota has its headquarters . His father worked at a trading company that employed about 30 people . His mother is a housewife . His family was n't particularly well-off . Of three sons , he alone went on to higher studies . One of his best friends from home never really got a job , but has become what the Japanese call a hikikomori -- a " shut-in person " rarely venturing out . " It 's not a psychological problem . He 's just a bit scared , or he does n't feel the need to work because he can live with his parents , " Ishikawa says . Nor is it an economic phenomenon . " Hikikomori come from both rich and poor families . And if you are really poor , you can not afford to lie around in bed all day . "
text: Ishikawa, 28, grew up in Kira, a small rice field town about an hour from the industrial city of Nagoya, where Toyota has its headquarters. His father worked in a trading company that employs about 30 employees. His mother is a housewife. His family is not particularly wealthy. Of the three sons, he continued to conduct higher research alone. One of his best friends at home never really found a job, but has become what the Japanese call hikikomori, a "closed person" rarely takes risks. "It's not a psychological problem. original_text: Afejuku uses the poem , " A Leaping Flame " to expose the belief among the Itsekiri that their land was stolen by those who have high connection in government . The poem is dedicated to the memory of Pa J. O. S Ayomike , a frontline Itsekiri activist and historian who fought for the sovereignty of the Itsekiri nation . In the poem , the speaker re-echoes the words of Pa Ayomike : ' Nothing is final , he chants . No one shall see the end/Until the land-owners of Oeeri regain and retain their lands/Stolen along the corridors and in the beds of love ' . Like several poems in Afejuku 's collections , there is the lingering hope that one day the Itsekiri nation will regain their ' stolen ' lands . A tone of resolute defiance runs through Afejuku 's poems . It constitutes a point of equi-balance to what might otherwise have been a hopeless view of life .
text: Afejuku uses the poem “Skipped Flame” to reveal Itsekiri’s belief that their land was stolen by those with high ties in the government. The poem is dedicated to the memory of Pa J. O. S Ayomike, a frontline Itsekiri activist and historian who fought for the sovereignty of Itsekiri Nation. In this poem, the speaker re-responds to Pa Ayomike's words: "Nothing is final, he shouts. No one will see the end until the Oeeri landowner recovers and retains its land along the corridor and on the bed of love / stolen." Like several poems in the Afejuku collection, one hopes that one day the Isekirian people will regain the "stolen" land. A firm tone of resistance permeates Afejuku's poems. It forms the balance point that might have been a desperate view of life.

original_text: High glucose in blood for prolonged period compromises the health of blood vessels , affecting various functions that are integral in maintaining blood flow to heart muscle . Uncontrolled diabetes decreases fluidity of blood making it more prone to clot . In addition , people with diabetes develop soft plaques that are more vulnerable to rupture in the coronary . Upon rupture it triggers clotting of blood which clogs the coronary artery causing heart attack .
text: High glucose in the blood for a long time can damage the health of blood vessels and affect various functions that maintain blood flow to the heart muscles. Uncontrolled diabetes can reduce blood flow, making it easier to clot. In addition, people with diabetes can develop soft plaques that are more susceptible to coronary rupture. After rupture, it triggers blood clotting, blocking the coronary artery and causing a heart attack.

original_text: Next , they carried out some tests in brain slices from mice , which were taken from a region of the brain called the hippocampus . This is the area affected in Alzheimer 's disease . They tested the effects of ADDL on neurones in these brain slices . They specifically looked at the effect on a nerve signalling phenomenon known as " long-term potentiation " , which strengthens the connection between neurones and is involved in learning and memory . They then tested whether prion protein needed to be present for ADDL to have an effect within the brain . To do this , they repeated their experiments using brain slices from mice that were genetically engineered to lack the prion protein . As well as using their laboratory-generated ADDL , they also repeated these experiments using amyloid beta extracted from the brain of a person with Alzheimer 's disease .
text: Next, they performed some tests in the mouse brain slices, taken from a brain area called the hippocampus. This is the area affected by Alzheimer's disease. They tested the effect of ADDL on neurons in these brain slices. They specifically investigated the effects on the phenomenon of neural signaling called “long-term enhancement,” which strengthens the connection between neurons and participates in learning and memory. They then tested whether the prion protein needed to be present to make a role in the brain. To do this, they repeated the experiment using brain sections from genetically designed mice that lacked the prion protein. In addition to using laboratory-generated ADDL, they repeated these experiments using amyloid ββ extracted from the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease.

It subtracts people who are looking for but cannot go to work and adds available people but is not looking for a job due to the following reasons: tired/believe no job, waiting for the results of a job application, temporary discomfort/disability, bad weather, and waiting for a re-work recall.

original_text: Most are from desperately poor Horn of Africa countries and like tens of thousands each year , were willing to risk the treacherous journey through war-torn and impoverished Yemen in the hope of finding work in Saudi Arabia and other wealthy Gulf Arab states . But their plan was not to be . Caught and detained by the Yemeni authorities , the 600 or so men now await deportation , prevented from leaving their makeshift jail by armed soldiers . Conditions at the warehouse are growing increasingly desperate . Several days ago , the authorities stopped handing out food and basic supplies . " I came from Djibouti to work . They used to give us small amounts of food . If there is no food , we will die , " said one migrant who declined to give his name . " If there is no solution , they will deport us to our countries or get us out of here " , the man added . Yemen , the poorest country on the Arabian Peninsula , has long been a transit point for migrants and refugees from East Africa , many of whom are fleeing hunger and violence . The route was unsafe long before Yemen descended into all-out war in 2015 . Hundreds drown each year on the perilous sea journey , and those who make it face multiple risks , including death by " assault , extortion and abuse by criminal networks , as well as the hazards stemming from the war in Yemen itself " , according to UNHCR , the United Nations ' refugee agency . Despite these dangers , the number of migrants traveling across the Gulf of Aden and Red Sea to Yemen has been rising steadily , to 117,000 in 2016 from 92,000 in 2015 , according to UNHCR . Khaled al-Elwany , a local official who until recently oversaw the deportation of migrants back to their home countries , says up to 15,000 migrants are arrested at city checkpoints each month . Elwany says he was fired by the interior ministry for refusing to cooperate with a plan to relocate the center to a neighboring province and after authorities stopped food supplies . A ministry official told Reuters that the aim of the move to a new facility had been to improve conditions for the migrants while they await deportation . Saudi Arabia and a coalition of mostly Gulf Arab allies are fighting to restore Yemen 's exiled government to power and roll back the Iran-aligned Houthi movement . While the government nominally controls Aden and other southern areas , a budget crunch and rivalries with local armed groups mean its officials mostly reside abroad . State services and salaries have been hit hard by the chaos , and the African migrants appear to be a lower priority . The frightened men in the Aden warehouse , subsisting on bread bought with meager savings and washing their clothes in an rubbish-strewn outdoor space , are just the tip of the iceberg .
text: Most people come from desperately poor countries in Africa, just like tens of thousands of years a year, willing to venture through the dangerous journey of war-torn Yemen, hoping to find jobs in Saudi Arabia and other wealthy Arab countries. But their plan is not. Now captured and detained by Yemeni authorities, 600 men who are now awaiting deportation have prevented armed soldiers from leaving the temporary prison. The conditions in the warehouse are getting more and more desperate. A few days ago, authorities stopped distributing food and basic supplies. "I'm from Jibouti to work. They used to give us a small amount of food. Without food, we would die," said an immigrant who refused to name it. "If there is no solution, they will deport us to our country or let us leave here." Yemen, the poorest country on the Arabian Peninsula, has long been a crossing point for migrants and refugees from East Africa, many of whom have fled hunger and violence. This route was unsafe in Yemen for a long time in the 2015 total war. UNHCR said hundreds of people were submerged in dangerous maritime journeys every year, and those who put them at multiple risks, including “crimes of attacks on criminal networks, extortion and abuse, and the harm caused by the Yemen war itself”. Despite these dangers, the number of immigrants across Aden and the Red Sea has been steadily rising, with the number of immigrants steadily rising to 117,000 in 2016 from 92,000 in 2015. Khaled Al-Elwany, a local official, until recently overseeing the deportation of immigrants back to his country, said as many as 15,000 migrants were arrested at city checkpoints each month. original_text: In Italy , a populist anti-establishment Five Star Movement ( M5S ) that contested the March 2018 Parliamentary elections under the slogan " Participate , Choose , Change " and a regionalist populist League that contested under the slogan " Italians First " formed an alliance this month to form government . The election environment also focused on the apparently irreversible decline of economy , persistent high unemployment and corruption. 1 The campaign of M5S was focussed on anti-corruption and a proposed Universal Basic Income ( UBI ) for all . The League was an anti-immigrant and anti-EU party like the National Front in France or United Kingdom Independence Party ( UKIP ) in Britain . It was formerly a separatist party that campaigned for autonomy of Padania , the richer northern parts of Italy .
text: In Italy, a populist anti-establishment five-star movement (M5S) competes with the March 2018 parliamentary elections under the slogan "Participate, choose, change" and a regional populist coalition that competes in the region that argues with "Italians" this month formed a coalition this month, which formed the government this month. The election environment is also concentrated on the economy, ongoing high unemployment rates and seemingly irreversible declines in corruption. 1 M5's campaign focuses on anti-corruption and the proposed universal basic income (UBI) for all. The Alliance is an anti-immigrant and anti-EU party, such as the National Front in France or the British Independence Party (UKIP). original_text: Bangladesh has become one of Asia 's most remarkable and unexpected success stories in recent years . Bangladesh, once one of Pakistan’s poorest areas, remained the economic basket for many years after independence in 1971 – destroyed by poverty and famine. In fact, the conditions by 2006 seemed so desperate that Bangladesh had registered faster than Pakistan and was therefore considered lucky. However, that year will be a turning point.

original_text: There have been more problems with the gold mining besides the immigration status of the Chinese miners . Ghanaians have also complained about the water and land pollution caused by the mining . The tension between the Chinese miners and locals , some of whom are gangsters , has been so high that many miners purchased weapons on the black market for protection . Problems in Africa Individual illegal miners are hardly the only problems involving China in Africa . In Ghana , six large Chinese companies legally mine gold there . In other African countries , more Chinese state-owned companies work on oil fields , construction sites , and in other enterprises . These large Chinese companies have been accused of abusing labor rights and causing environmental damage .

Ghanaians also complain about water and land pollution caused by mining. Tensions between Chinese miners and locals, some of them gangsters, are so high that many miners buy weapons on the black market for protection. The issue of illegal African individual miners is not the only problem involving China in Africa. In Ghana, six large Chinese companies legally dug gold there. original_text: Ferdinand Pecora was little known outside New York until 1933 . The former New York prosecutor was called to Washington to become chief counsel of Senate hearings looking into Wall Street 's wrongdoings that led to the Crash of 1929 . Pecora is a surprising hero of the time -- he was a poor Italian immigrant who earned his legal education at night school . And over a ten-day period , he grilled some of the titans of Wall Street , toppling one of them -- multimillionaire Charles Mitchell , aka Sunshine Charley -- who was chairman of National City Bank , the predecessor of the current-day Citibank . NPR 's Robert Siegel talks to Michael Perino , a law professor and former Wall Street litigator , about his new book , The Hellhound of Wall Street : How Ferdinand Pecora 's Investigation of the Great Crash Forever Changed American Finance .
text: Until 1933, Ferdinand Pecora was little known outside New York. The former New York prosecutor was asked to go to Washington to become chief adviser for the Senate hearing, studying Wall Street's wrongdoing that led to the 1929 plane crash. Pecora was a surprising hero of the time - a poor Italian immigrant who received a legal education at night school. Over a ten-day period, he roasted some of Wall Street's Titans, one of the champions - multimillionaire Charles Mitchell, also known as Sunshine Charley, who was the chairman of the National City Bank, the predecessor of today's Citibank. NPR's Robert Siegel talks with law professor and former Wall Street litigator Michael Perino about his new book "Hell on Wall Street: How Ferdinand Pecora's investigation into big accidents changes U.S. finance forever.

original_text: The mixing of forced and economic migration , the so-called mixed migration flows , represents a tricky policy-issue . Many ( economic ) migrants are trying to receive a residence permit in a destination country by filing an ( often hopeless ) asylum application . One consequence is an additional burden for asylum systems in host countries . This study captures the dynamics of mixed migration with the available data and offers policy recommendations to improve mechanisms for handling the phenomenon . Click here for a video summarizing the findings . <h> New Social Europe Book
text: The so-called forced and mixed migration flows of hybrid migration represent a thorny policy issue. Many (economic) immigrants attempt to obtain residence permits in their destination country by making (usually desperate) asylum applications. One of the results is an additional burden on the host country’s asylum system. This study captures the dynamics of hybrid migration and provides available data and provides policy recommendations to improve mechanisms for handling the phenomenon. Click here to view a video of the research results. <h>New Society European Books

original_text: The enormity of the defence budget , which stands at INR 1,93,407.29 crore for the current fiscal year , makes it vulnerable to massive cuts as a means of fiscal adjustment . It is , therefore , natural that defence expenditure would come under a close scrutiny by the Ministry of Finance , which is desperate to contain the fiscal deficit during the current year . Reduction in budgetary allocations is not unprecedented and it is unlikely to be any different this year . As reported in the press last week , spending on even the social sector is likely to come down , with the Finance Ministry threatening to cut down the allocation by as much as 40 per cent for the sake of fiscal consolidation . Under the circumstances , the Ministry of Defence would be lucky to get away with a 10 per cent cut , even if it can ill afford it .
text: The defence budget is huge in the current fiscal year at INR 193.4072.9 billion, which makes it vulnerable to massive cuts. Therefore, naturally, defense spending will be carefully scrutinized by the Ministry of Finance, which is eager to curb the fiscal deficit in that year. The reduction in budget allocation is not unprecedented and it is unlikely to be any different this year. As reported last week, even social sector spending could fall, with the Treasury threatening to reduce distribution by up to 40% for fiscal consolidation. In this case, the Department of Defense will be lucky enough to be able to reduce the cuts by 10%, even if it can't afford it.

He does not support creating new citizenship for undocumented workers.

original_text: The Chinese Spring Festival takes place between the 7th and the 13th of February . Usually , demand for fruit rises during this National Holiday week . However , Owen Zhang , banana import manager at Goodfarmer , does not expect banana prices to rise sharply this week . ? ' The economic situation is currently unstable . Many migrant workers already turned home due to lack of jobs in big cities . This will bring urban consumption down . Most dealers find it hard to make correct assumptions about demand during the Spring Festival , which can lead to oversupply , pushing prices down . The weather has not been positive for the industry either . The extreme cold of the last week , which is expected to last , makes consumers stay at home . This makes it extra difficult to predict how sales will go .
text: The Chinese Spring Festival is held between February 7 and 13. Usually, demand for fruits rises during this national holiday week. But Owen Zhang, the banana import manager at Goodfarmer, does not want banana prices to rise sharply this week. ? 'The economic situation is currently unstable. Many migrant workers have moved home due to the lack of jobs in big cities. This will reduce urban consumption. Most dealers find it difficult to make the right assumptions about demand during the Spring Festival, which can lead to oversupply and thus lower prices. The weather is not positive for the industry either. The extreme cold was expected to keep consumers at home last week. This makes it very difficult to predict sales growth.

original_text: A recent Star piece by two criminologists brought a new gaze to the idea of community . It examined reconstruction of public housing in Toronto 's Regent Park , where many poor families were moved out while middle class homes were built , then moved back alongside the newbies . The theory was to spread good influence , like fairy dust , from the successful to the benighted , providing " positive role models who could transmit more mainstream standards of behaviour . " The criminologists found there was n't much influence , since there was n't much contact . And more scandalously , the underclasses did n't feel their standards needed heavy upgrading . In fact , their own solid values of community and mutual support were somewhat undermined by the transformations . That 's too brief but I found it a stimulating springboard for thoughts about community .
text: The recent celebrity work of two criminologists has brought new gazes to the community’s ideas. It examines the reconstruction of public housing in Toronto Regent Park, where many impoverished families were moved out while building middle-class homes and then moved back with newbies. The theory is to spread good influences (such as fairy tale dust) from successful people to local good influences, providing a positive example of "can spread more mainstream standards of behavior." Criminologists found that there was not much impact because there was not much exposure. What’s even more annoying is that the lower classes do not think that their standards require a lot of upgrades. In fact, their own communities and solid values ​​of mutual support are undermined by the transformation. It's too short, but I found it an exciting springboard for ideas about the community.

So, in the United States, white supremacists, like European rivals, have been selling worrying statistics, and unless the influx of outsiders from Asia, Africa and Latin America (legal immigrants and non-legal persons) are completely stopped, they will become a minority in the United States for the next 25 years. original_text: The 17 stories in At The End of the Century , drawn from past collections , chronicle Jhabvala 's concern with cultural encounters , dislocation and the immigrant experience . Misogyny -- and sensuality -- bubble up through impeccably constructed prose . In The Widow , Durga fails to seduce a teenager -- whom she describes as " a young animal full of sap and sperm " -- renting one of her rooms with his family . Shamed into spirituality , urged to pray to Krishna " as a son and as a lover " , Durga duly renounces her widow 's fortune and her relatives move in , happily reaping the benefits .
text: 17 stories from the end of this century are drawn from past collections, the Chronicle’s focus on cultural encounters, dislocations and immigration experiences. Misogyny - and sexy - bubbling through impeccable prose bubbles. Among the widows, Durga fails to seduce a teenager - she describes as "a young animal full of juice and sperm" - rents one of her rooms with her family. Durga was willing to pray to Krishna "as son and lover", and Durga gave up her legacy wealth appropriately, and her relatives moved in and happily reaped the benefits.

original_text: Six-year-old Sandra moved to the capital city , Abuja with her family . She has four siblings and her father is a taxi driver , while her mother fries and sells akara outside the uncompleted building they live in . Her father had learned that there was money in the thriving taxi business in the capital city and they had left their village in search of greener pastures , only that it did not seem so green here , in the decrepit looking building where she and her siblings are left vulnerable each day as their parents step out the door to make a living .
text: Sandra, six, moved with her family to the capital Abuja. She has four siblings, her father is a taxi driver, while her mother fries and sells Akara outside the unfinished building where they live. Her father learned that there was money in the capital’s booming taxi business, they left the villages for greener pastures, but they didn’t look that green here, and in the aging buildings, she and her siblings were vulnerable every day as their parents walked out to make a living.

original_text: As a child , I have always been told to give to those who are in need . I have been raised up to believe that if I do n't give to the needy , I will find my way to hell . Due to these teachings that has been imbued in me , I have been generally been sympathetic to the needy . After all it is said in the Holy Scriptures that " there is blessing in giving than receiving " . Growing up , I have however disabused my mind of this notion . I am just tired of seeing a familiar face beg on the street for far too long , I am tired of giving money to a beggar who asks me for money today and yet shamefully ask me for help again when he or she meets me on the next day .
text: As a kid, I was always told to donate to those in need. I have grown up and believe that if I don’t give to those in need, I will find the way to hell. Since these teachings have filled me, I usually always sympathize with those in need. After all, it is said in the Bible that “give more blessings than received.” When I grew up, I was disdainful of the idea. I was just tired of seeing a familiar face begging on the street for too long, I was tired of donating money to beggar, who asked me for money today but when he or she met me the next day, he shamefully asked me for help.

original_text: How did we get here ? To answer that , you have to go back to 1986 and the work of an eccentric and powerful California politician , John " Vasco " Vasconcellos . That year , the Democrat Vasconcellos managed to persuade a deeply sceptical Republican state governor to fund a three-year task force to explore the value of self-esteem . Vasco was convinced that low self-esteem was the source of a huge array of social issues , including unemployment , educational failure , child abuse , domestic violence , homelessness and gang warfare . He became convinced that raising the population 's self-esteem would act as a " social vaccine " , saving the state billions .
text: How did we get here? To answer this you have to go back to 1986, and the work of John "Vasco" Vasconcellos, a quirky and powerful California politician. That year, Democrat Vasconcellos managed to convince a skeptical Republican governor to fund a three-year task force that explores self-esteem. Vasco firmly believes that low self-esteem is the root of a range of social problems, including unemployment, education failure, child abuse, domestic violence, homelessness and gang wars. He is convinced that increasing the population's self-esteem will serve as a "social vaccine" that saves billions of dollars in the country.

original_text: Mother Nature does not make fine distinctions between legal and illegal , skilled or unskilled immigrants . She ca n't distinguish immigrants from refugees , legitimate from illegitimate asylum-seekers , white from black or European from Asian or Hispanic migrants , or those who climb aboard via the airport from those who enter through the maternity ward . All human passengers have footprints whatever their origin , and no category of humanity earns an exemption from her law of Carrying Capacity . Some believe that Mother Nature can be fooled or appeased by technical improvements that grow a phantom capacity , but that capacity only enables the addition of more passengers . No technological con job can win us a permanent reprieve from her determination to adjust the number of passengers to the limited capacity of our boat .
text: Mother Nature does not have a good distinction between law and illegal, skilled or unskilled immigrants. She did not distinguish between immigration from refugees, legal asylums, black or white people in Europe from Asian or Hispanic immigrants, or people who climbed up through airports and people who entered through pregnant wards. All human passengers, regardless of their origin, have footprints, and no human category can be exempted from her law of carrying capacity. Some believe that Mother Nature can deceive or soothe through technical improvements that enhance the ability of phantoms, but that ability can only add more passengers. There is no technical scam that can be permanently probated from her determination to adjust the number of passengers to a limited capacity of a limited ship.

Though based in Karachi and utilising the distinctly Pakistani quandaries of political instability and terrorist-induced chaos , Saba Imtiaz manages to weave a story that is as cosmopolitan in essence as it is Pakistani . text: Located in Karachi, Saba Imtiaz is taking advantage of the apparent Pakistani refugees who are chaotic by political unrest and terrorism, but Saba Imtiaz manages to weave a story that is essentially international like the Pakistani. Bringing the Kurtas and rickshaws out of the equation, this novel may be about any woman who struggles to carve a niche in any international city around the world. Like ambitious young professionals around the world, Ayesha almost always needs alcohol to provide some much-needed Dutch art and escapism from what she calls the Tight Rope of Life.

original_text: Lucas Radebe knows what he is talking about , and also knows just how hard the route out of poverty , hopelessness , and violence can be . After apartheid was abolished 16 years ago , South Africa experienced a substantial economic boom . Yet for the majority of the population life is anything but easy . In 2009 the unemployment rate was running at 23.6% according to the World Bank . There is a huge gulf between rich and poor . Like many other African countries , South Africa has also been seriously affected by HIV/AIDS . In 2009 , 17% of all South Africans aged between 15 and 49 suffered from AIDS . According to the World Health Organization ( WHO ) this immune deficiency disease has now become the most common cause of death in South Africa , even in children .
text: Lucas Radebe knows what he is talking about and also knows the difficult road to getting rid of poverty, despair and violence. South Africa experienced substantial economic prosperity after apartheid was abolished 16 years ago. However, it is by no means easy for most populations to live. According to the World Bank, the unemployment rate in 2009 was 23.6%. There is a huge gap between the rich and the poor. Like many other African countries, South Africa is also severely affected by HIV/AIDS. In 2009, 17% of all South Africans aged 15 to 49 had AIDS. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), this immunodeficiency disease is now the most common cause of death in South Africa, even in children.

original_text: Police officers who have acquired additional academic qualifications will not enjoy increased salaries after the decision was rescinded . Those who were awarded pay rises on the basis of such qualifications will not only retain their original salaries but designations as well . The National Police Service Commission ( NPSC ) has consequently directed Inspector General of Police Joseph Boinnet to stop the additional payments . Also affected are disabled officers , who will no longer enjoy tax exemptions . This takes effect this month . The law in Kenya exempts the disabled from paying taxes for monthly earnings of Sh150,000 and below . Beneficiaries of the pay review were officers who improved their academic qualifications . Others had been exempted from paying taxes after they were recognised as disabled people . Read more at : https : **39;170;TOOLONG ...
text: After the decision is revoked, police officers who have obtained additional education will not be paid more. Those who receive compensation based on such qualifications will not only retain their original salary, but also their name. Therefore, the National Police Commission (NPSC) directed Police Attorney General Joseph Boinnet to stop additional payments. Disabled officials have also been affected and they will no longer enjoy tax exemptions. This is effective this month. Kenya’s law exempts people with disabilities from taxes earning 150,000 and below per month. The beneficiary of the salary review is an officer who improves his or her education. Others are exempt from tax payments after being recognized as persons with disabilities. Read more: https: ** 39; 170; toolong...

original_text: In Oregon , a higher share of poor families is on welfare ( now called TANF , or Temporary Aid to Needy Families ) than in most states . The state has some of the highest food-stamp uptake in the country . It subsidizes childcare for working parents , asking the poorest of them to contribute as little as $27 a month . It helps people get off of welfare by linking them to employment and paying their wages for up to six months , and then allows them to continue to receive food stamps as they transition to higher wages . Families can be on welfare for up to 60 months , as opposed to 24 months in many other states , and once the parents are cut off due to time limits , their children can still continue to receive aid .
text: In Oregon, poor families account for a higher proportion of poor families (now known as Tanf or temporary assistance to families in need). The state has some of the highest food stamp absorption in the country. It provides parenting subsidies for working parents, requiring the poorest of them to contribute $27 a month. It can help people get rid of benefits by linking them to hiring and paying six months’ wages, and then allow them to continue to accept food stamps as they transition to higher wages. Families can enjoy up to 60 months of benefits, while in many other states 24 months, their children can still continue to receive assistance once parents are cut off due to time constraints.

original_text: The LGBT movement has created vast opportunities for us to have better lives than could have been dreamed of in 1969 . But as life has gotten so much better for most of us , it is still horrific for our homeless LGBT youths . As we grow in freedom and power , youths are ever more emboldened to come out . And too many of them are still rejected by their families and driven to the streets . We have fought to protect the rights of LGBT people and have won remarkable victories . But for our homeless LGBT youths not much has changed since 1969 . There are at least 200,000 homeless LGBT youths on the streets of the U.S.A. And despite our power and accomplishments as a movement , we have only created about 350 housing units dedicated to these 200,000 homeless LGBT youths . And so in 2014 our kids continue to suffer in the cold , and be hurt and exploited in the streets , as Danny was in 1969 .
text: The LGBT campaign has created a huge opportunity for us to dream of 1969. But as most of us lives get better, it’s still terrible for us homeless young LGBT people. As our freedom and strength develop, young people become more courageous. Too many of them were still rejected by their families and drove to the streets. We strive to protect the rights of the LGBT people and have won outstanding victories. But for us homeless young people of LGBT, there hasn't been much change since 1969. There are at least 200,000 homeless LGBT youth on the streets of the United States, and despite our strength and achievements as a movement, we have created only about 350 housing units dedicated to these 200,000 homeless LGBT youths. So in 2014, our children continued to suffer in the cold and were hurt and exploited on the streets like Danny did.

Unless Congress acts , millions of people on fixed incomes would get an automatic 21% cut in benefits , reports The Associated Press .

The trustees who oversee social security said the plan had enough money to pay the full benefits until 2034. But by then, Social Security will only charge enough taxes to pay 79% of the benefits. Millions of fixed income individuals will automatically cut benefits by 21% unless Congress takes action, according to the Associated Press.

original_text: As far as Kashmir is concerned , it 's something I 've always turned over in my mind . I was in Kashmir once when I was sixteen , when insurgency was beginning to take off after which it became really difficult to travel there . We visited the ancestral village of Kunzergaon not too far away from Srinagar . At that time , there was still a pandit in Multan who kept the family genealogy intact that he recited to us . One of my cousins who is a filmmaker had been back there recently . He said that the temple is gone and the pandits are scattered completely . In other words , I 've lost the few connections I had with the valley . My family left Kashmir in the very early part of 19th century . Their migrant community is around Agra , Lucknow and Kanpur . Later they seeped into Jaipur and the rest of Rajasthan . I 've heard among some circles that there are Punjabi Pandits who do n't speak Kashmiri anymore .
text: As far as Kashmir is concerned, this is always in my mind. I used to be in Kashmir when I was 16, when the rebellion started to take off and it was really hard to get there after that. We visited Kunzergaon, a ancestral village not far from Srinagar. At that time, there was still a Pandit in Multan who kept the family tree intact and made him recite it to us. One of my cousins ​​is a filmmaker and has been back there recently. He said the temple had disappeared and the Pandits were completely scattered. In other words, I lost several connections to the valley. My family left Kashmir in the early 19th century. Their immigrant communities are near Agra, Lucknow and Kanpur. Later, they infiltrated Jaipur and other parts of Rajasthan. I have heard in some circles that there are Punjabi people who stop talking about Kashmiris anymore.

text: The requirements for eligible for VAT exemption are broad. Not only must the company have a disability of 25% of its workforce, but the company must also have at least ten employees with disabilities. In fact, this means that the exemption only applies to large companies. For example, if a small startup with 16 employees has a workforce of 50% of people with disabilities, they still do not qualify for VAT exemption.

original_text: Kenya is leading the world in mobile money , with more than 18.2 million active Kenyan customers relying on the M-Pesa mobile payments platform . In fact , users of Kenya 's M-Pesa now send money totaling 20 percent of the country 's GDP to each other each year via text message . Kenya serves as a shining example of the incredible impact mobile payments can have on individuals , communities and economies at large . While we may think that the U.S. is leaps ahead of a developing country like Kenya when it comes to mobile payments , the truth is , the majority of money transfers in the U.S. -- upward of 80 percent , according to some estimates -- are taking place domestically . The U.S. is in need of an effective P2P transfer system just as much as Kenya was before M-Pesa .

In fact, Kenya’s M-PESA users now pay each other 20% of the country’s GDP each year via text messages. Kenya is a shiny example of the incredible impact of mobile payments on individuals, communities and economies. While we may think the U.S. has made a leap forward in mobile payments, the fact is that, by some estimates, most of the transfers of most currency transfers in the U.S. (more than 80%) are underway at home. The United States needs an effective P2P transfer system, just like Kenya before M-PESA.

After a series of visits and a series of visits he lived with me and a lot of conversations we stayed in touch and about two years ago. I won't be with him. original_text: At the UN climate conference , where all countries sit together to negotiate , we , the developing countries -- particularly the most vulnerable countries -- have long been asking for compensation . The rich countries do n't like the word compensation . So , we have a euphemism for that . It 's called " loss and damage . " After a long battle and discussion , we finally got them to agree in the Paris Agreement to include an article on loss and damage . This article now allows us to discuss about loss and damage , and ask for compensation .
text: At the UN Climate Conference, all countries sit there for negotiations, and we, developing countries, especially the most vulnerable countries – have long been demanding compensation. Rich countries do not like compensation words. Therefore, we have euphemisms about this. It is called "loss and damage." After a long battle and discussion, we finally got them to agree to the Paris Agreement, which included articles on losses and damages. Now, this article allows us to discuss losses and damages and ask for compensation.

original_text: Everything up to 1966 had been going marvelously in Beatleland . They had crushed and conquered the musical world , were four of the most recognizable faces on the planet , and each was now a multi-millionaire with a legacy enshrined in myth . Touring was taking its toll , of course . And since their introduction to LSD their nervous systems were starting to shred with the constant whirlwind of press conferences , disturbed fans , hordes of disabled children asking " to be healed " , and general mob hysteria . But still , 1966 was full steam ahead . Then John opened his mouth and everything changed forever .
text: Everything was outstanding in Strand by 1966. They crushed and conquered the music world, were the four most well-known faces on the planet, and now everyone is a multimillionaire with a mythical legacy. Of course, the tour is causing losses. Since their introduction to LSD, their nervous system has begun to rise with the ongoing whirlwind of news conferences, disrupted fans, hordes of disabled children demanding “healing” and the hysteria of the mob general. But despite this, 1966 was still full of motivation. Then John opened his mouth and everything changed.

original_text: This clearly distinguishes abuses of human rights -- whether committed in Myanmar or elsewhere , which gives the United Nations Security Council the authority to intervene , from matters of State such as the mismanagement of a State which we see from time to time where the UN is destitute of authority to intervene . text: This clearly distinguishes the abuse of human rights – both in Myanmar and elsewhere, which gives the UN Security Council the right to intervene, such as the mismanagement of the state we see from time to time, and the United Nations has no authority to intervene. One way a family crisis can lead to international peace is that it causes refugees to flee the border, thus threatening peace in neighboring countries. Another is that if any party involved in the domestic conflict spreads its tentacles to other parts of the world, threatening domestic or international peace in other regions outside the region where the crisis occurs

original_text: Although policy change is needed in the early childhood development sector in South Africa , the first step is a change in mind-set . When people see the conditions learned by poor families, it is obvious that we do not value poor black children. Their lives and future prospects are not valued as much as they should. In addition, we need to recognize the importance of the first few years of our child’s life. This is a period of rapid development, greater than any other time in a person's life. In addition, not only does the children’s early experience shape their lifelong learning, but it also affects their physical and mental health.

original_text: NEW DELHI : Catholic leaders in India Friday slammed the national women 's rights watchdog for seeking to ban church confessions after two priests were arrested for allegedly raping and blackmailing a woman over 20 years . Two more priests are being investigated in the scandal that has rocked the Syrian Orthodox church in the southern state of Kerala since the 34-year-old woman reported her cycle of abuse earlier this month . The woman told police that the priests at the church used her confessions to blackmail her into having sex with them . India 's National Commission for Women Thursday called on the government to scrap confessions in all churches , saying they were being used to blackmail vulnerable women . The recommendation was made in a report to the government on sexual abuse in the church . The Kerala Catholic Bishops Council said the demand had hurt the religious sentiments of India 's Christian minority .
text: New Delhi: India's Catholic leaders on Friday slammed the national women's rights regulator for seeking a ban on church confession after two pastors were arrested for allegedly raped and extorted a woman for 20 years. Two other pastors have been investigated amid a scandal that rocked Syrian Orthodox churches in southern Kerala since the 34-year-old woman reported a cycle of abuse earlier this month. The woman told police that the church priest used her confession to blackmail her to have sex with them. India's National Women's Commission on Thursday called on the government to cancel confessions in all churches, saying they are used to extorting vulnerable women. The recommendation was made in a report to the government on sexual abuse in the church. The Kerala Catholic Bishops Council said demand has damaged religious sentiment in the Christian minority in India.

original_text: How long must families who lost loved ones in Bangladesh 's catastrophic factory disaster wait for compensation ? The shoddily-built Rana Plaza in Dhaka collapsed on April 24 , killing or injuring most of its 4,000 workers in a tragedy that stirred international sympathy and outrage . Yet five months on most of the poor families involved are getting nothing like the help they should , adding insult to tragedy .
text: How long must families who have lost their loved ones in a catastrophic factory disaster in Bangladesh? The wooden Rana Plaza in Dhaka collapsed on April 24, killing or blowing the majority of 4,000 workers, arousing international sympathy and anger. original_text: Relief programmes are being scaled up to meet rising needs , but to save lives and prevent decades of development progress from being irreversibly eroded , more must be done . We need to provide more people with desperately needed cash and food assistance . We need to reach more children with specialised nutritional support to stop greater numbers from becoming malnourished . And we need to expand social safety nets that buffer the impact of this crisis , such as school feeding programmes so children from poor families get at least one good meal a day . The urgency of the situation is irrefutable . But humanitarian aid is not keeping pace with the tremendous needs . Not even close . In fact , there is a staggering funding gap -- and it is a tragedy in the making .
text: Relief programs are expanding to meet growing demand, but more must be done to save lives and prevent decades of irreversible erosion of development and progress. We need to provide much-needed cash and food assistance to more people. We need to attract more children with specialized nutritional support to stop more people from being malnourished. And we need to expand social safety nets to alleviate the impact of this crisis, such as school feeding programs, so that children from impoverished families can eat at least one good meal a day. The urgency of this situation is irrefutable. But humanitarian aid has not kept up with the huge demand. Not even closed. In fact, there is an astonishing funding gap - it is a tragedy.

original_text: New York in the 1920s was a mess . Let down by its venal politicians , the city 's transport was hopeless and its housing dreadful . Then along came a man with a plan . A grand plan . His name was Robert Moses . Armed with autocratic powers , and fuelled by a titanic megalomania , the urban planner ruthlessly transformed the place . Some of what he did in park creation and bridge construction was magnificent ; much of his legacy was terrible . Expressways were sliced through neighbourhoods as he prioritised cars over people . His construction projects had scant regard for the fabric or the quality of human life . Scores of traditional communities were ripped apart . Hundreds of thousands of people were displaced . All in the name of progress . And masterminded by a man who was never elected to anything .
text: New York in the 1920s was a mess. Due to the disappointment of the Naar politicians, the city's transportation was hopeless and the houses were frightening. Then there is a planned person. A grand plan. His name is Robert Moses. The city planners changed the place ruthlessly among the giant fanatics of the Titanic. Some of the things he did in park creation and bridge construction were grand. Much of his legacy is terrible. The highways prioritize cars over people and slice them through the community. His architectural projects have little consideration for the structure or quality of human life. Dozens of traditional communities have been torn apart. Thousands of people are displaced. All in the name of progress. It is mastered by a person who has never been elected for anything.

original_text: At the moment , companies can save money by outsourcing STEM jobs to places like India and the Philippines , where employees cost less . But it is still true that immigrants have rejuvenated the lifeblood of this country since its inception , and provided the intellectual and economic seed corn that has truly , to repeat a phrase , made this country great . They , along with American-born kids who ca n't afford fancy private schools , need a pathway to help keep the nation strong . American high schools can and must do a better job of preparing students for the STEM sector , the first step in a pipeline running through college and into industry . That will mean investing in the infrastructure that the high-school STEM curriculum requires . It also means renewing our faith that our own students , from all communities , have the potential to compete and win on the global stage , if given proper preparation .
text: Currently, companies can save money by outsourcing STEM work to places like India and the Philippines, which are at a lower cost. But since the founding of the country, immigration has still restored the lifeblood of the country and provided intellectual and economic seed corn, which is truly to repeat the sentence and make the country great. Together with American-born children who can’t afford private schools, they need a way to help keep the country strong. American high schools can and must do better, preparing students for the STEM industry, the first step in the pipeline that runs through colleges and industries. This will mean investing in the infrastructure required for high school STEM courses. It also means re-believing our own students, students from all communities, have the potential to compete and win on the global stage, if properly prepared.

original_text: 5 . What are the benefits of the " provisional waiver " program ? This procedure would allow qualified aliens , with a US citizen or LPR parent or spouse , to apply for a waiver of the 3/10 year bar , while still in the US , and before they depart the US for immigrant visa processing overseas . If the waiver is granted , they would then depart the US ( with the approved waiver in hand ) , and would not have to wait several months outside the US to process that 3/10 year bar waiver .
text: 5. What are the benefits of the “temporary waiver” program? The program will allow qualified foreigners to apply for a 3/10 year bar exemption with a U.S. citizen or LPR parent or spouse while still in the U.S. to undergo overseas immigration visa processing before they leave the U.S. If the exemption is approved, they will leave the U.S. (the exemption approved at hand) and do not have to wait a few months outside the U.S. to handle the 3/10 year bar exemption.

original_text: On December 23 , the Ministry of Finance ( MOF ) and the State Administration of Taxation ( SAT ) jointly released the " Announcement on the Abolishment of Governmental Funds for Small and Micro Enterprises ( Cai Shui 2014 No.122 ) . " The circular exempts small and micro-sized enterprises whose monthly sales are less than RMB 30,000 or entities making quarterly payments whose sales are less than RMB 90,000 , from governmental funds charges . These refer to China 's educational surcharge , local educational surcharge , water conservancy construction charge and cultural construction fee . Furthermore , eligible small and micro-size enterprises hiring fewer than 20 employees shall be exempt from social security payments for the employment of disabled people . The Announcement will take effect on January 1 , 2015 and last until December 21 , 2017 . Since 2012 , China has released a series of preferential policies to support the development of small and micro enterprises .

original_text: The early story of Yahoo is now Silicon Valley mythology . It was a convenient map of the digital landscape that was not to be moved at the time, and web surfers loved it. The following year, when Sequoia Capital invested in a newly renamed startup, it put Tim Koogle, a former Motorola executive as CEO.

original_text: First of all , while , of course , it is the individual who directly benefits from college education in terms of acquiring more knowledge and skills , which translates to more job opportunities , it is not the individual alone who benefits . In a poor country such as the Philippines where wages are low and labor is cheap , the college education of a member of a family , especially for the poor , is their only way out of poverty . It is also the only way by which the future family of that same family member could break free from the quagmire of poverty that has enveloped his or her family for generations . It is about social mobility . And if more poor families break free from poverty , would that not reflect on the development of Philippine society ?
text: First, of course, it is one who benefits directly from college education by gaining more knowledge and skills, which translates into more employment opportunities, but not individual benefits. In a poor country, such as the Philippines where wages are low and labor-expensive, college education for family members (especially for the poor) is their only way out of poverty. This is also the only way for the same family to escape poverty in the future, which has shrouded the poverty that his or her family has passed down from generation to generation. It's about social mobility. Moreover, if more poor families get rid of poverty, will it reflect the development of Filipino society?

original_text: Sandra Day O'Connor famously had a cushion in her chambers hand-embroidered with the words " Maybe in error but never in doubt . " Of all the memorable qualities O'Connor modeled as the first female justice , to my mind the most crucial was her unwillingness to stew or fret over past mistakes or to become immobilized by fears that she did n't know enough . O'Connor was often maddening for liberals because she evinced few regrets over her vote in Bush v. Gore , and she was often content to decide cases as if hers was the only worldview that mattered . But to me , O'Connor will always stand for the idea that when in doubt , do n't be in doubt . That 's a useful lesson for women pondering running for office , going to law school , or organizing a protest in the coming years .
text: Sandra Day O'Connor on her Chambers hand-carved mat read "Maybe it's wrong, but never doubt it." Among all the memorable qualities, O'Connor imitated as the first female justice, and in my opinion, the most crucial thing is that she is unwilling to endure past mistakes or unwilling to bother her enough, or knowing she is not enough to overwhelm her. O'Connor is often angry with liberals because she rarely regrets the vote in Bush v. Gore, and she is often content to decide cases as if she was the only important worldview. But for me, O'Connor will always represent the idea: If you have any questions, don't doubt it. This is a useful lesson for women who are running for office, going to law school or organizing protests in the coming years.

original_text: Microfinance is defined in the Regulations as the viable and sustainable provision of a broad range of financial services to poor and low-income individuals engaged in livelihood and microenterprise activities . It uses non-traditional and innovative methodologies and approaches to provide microfinance loans , microinsurance , enterprise development , health care , and microhousing to poor families . When managed correctly , access to convenient , flexible and reasonably-priced financial services can be used to establish small businesses and develop other long-term income-generating activities .
text: Microfinance is defined in regulations as the feasibility and sustainability of providing a wide range of financial services to poor and low-income individuals engaged in livelihoods and micro-enterprise activities. It uses non-traditional and innovative approaches and approaches to provide microfinance loans, microinsurance, corporate development, health care and microfamily. After proper management, convenient, flexible and reasonable financial services can be used to build small businesses and develop other long-term revenue-generating activities.

original_text: When the LTTE choppers started hovering over the Colombo night skies on April 26 , 2007 when the nation was busy watching the Cricket World Cup finals , the Sri Lankans got its closest experience to September 11 , 2001 . We lost the match and also the hope of war victory . The world 's most sophisticated terrorist outfit was calling shots here as never before . Al Qaeda carried out attacks with hijacked planes , the LTTE had its own air wing . Just like it happened after the Al-Qaeda attacks on Twin towers in Manhattan and the Pentagon , stunned and petrified masses here started predicting doomsday scenarios . Fear and hopelessness ruled for days and weeks .
text: On April 26, 2007, when the LTTE choppers began to hover over the Colombo night sky while the United States was busy watching the World Cup finals, the Sri Lankans gained the closest experience to September 11, 2001. We lost the game and the hope of victory in the war. The most complex terrorists in the world have never hit here as they did before. Al Qaeda attacked with a hijacked plane, and the LTTE had its own air wings. Just as this happened after Al Qaeda's attack on the Twin Towers of Manhattan and the Pentagon, the shocked and troubled masses here are starting to predict the end of the world. Fear and despair ruled for days and weeks.

original_text: The conflict in Syria continues to drive the largest displacement crisis in the world . By mid-2018 , Turkey hosted over 3.5 million Syrian refugees , of which around 70 percent are women or children In 2017 , there was a 21 percent increase in the refugee population in Turkey , from 2.9 million at the beginning of 2017 to 3.5 million at the end of the year . The previous administration implemented this program , which aims to support extremely poor families to meet their most immediate needs , and to break the intergenerational poverty cycle by investing in the health and education of poor children . That is why poor households receive health grants of P500 per month and education grant of P300 per child per month .
text: The Pantawid Sa Pamilyang Pilipino Program (4PS) or what some people call the Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) is a transfer payment. The last government implemented the program, which aims to support families in extreme poverty to meet their most immediate needs and to break the intergenerational poverty cycle by investing in the health and education of children in need. This is why poor families receive a monthly health grant of P500 and a monthly education grant of P300 for children.

Officials said future relief items will also be distributed among the poor.

original_text: In the study , authors reviewed data collected from the Upstate KIDS study , which originally sought to determine if fertility treatments could affect child development from birth through age 3 . text: In the study, the authors reviewed data collected from the Upstate Children's Study, which initially sought to determine whether fertility treatment affects development of children from birth to 3 years of age. Between 2008 and 2010, about 4 months after delivery in New York State (excluding New York City), more than 5,000 women participated in the study. To assess development, parents completed the age and stage questionnaire after a series of activities with their children. This test is not used to diagnose a specific disability but serves as a screen for potential problems, so children can be referred for further testing.
